author: Schuyler Kropf
title: Joe Riley endorsing Hillary Clinton for president
text:
FILE Former Secretary of State and presidential hopeful Hillary Rodham Clinton, Charleston mayor Joe Riley (center) and U.S. Rep. Jim Clyburn, D-S.C. × The biggest Lowcountry “get” in the Democratic race for the White House is going to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

Less than 24 hours after Riley’s first choice — Vice President Joe Biden — bowed out, Riley said he will support Clinton for president.
Up until this week, Riley had told everyone in the state’s political circles that he would be a lock for Biden if the VP opted to get in the race.
But once Biden chose against it, Riley said he made contact with the Clinton campaign Wednesday night to say he would be in her camp.
“I respect her very much,” Riley said Thursday. “I think she would make an excellent president.”
The mayor said he met both Bill and Hillary Clinton in the 1980s when he had a leadership role with the U.S. Council of Mayors. At the time she was an advocate with the Children’s Defense Fund and spoke out in support of preventing teenage pregnancies, he said.
Riley said Biden had been his first choice, saying a friendship had grown out of his time in the Obama administration stemming from Charleston-related issues. Biden already had deep connections in South Carolina tied to friendships with former Sens. Fritz Hollings and the late Sen. Strom Thurmond. He has been a repeat visitor to the area as well for vacations and breaks.
Biden’s exit is expected to send other sidelined Democrats Clinton’s way and free up new sources of campaign cash as well.
Clinton is scheduled to be in Charleston next week to speak to the Charleston branch of the NAACP’s 98th annual Freedom Fund Banquet as the keynote speaker.
Seven years ago, Riley skipped on backing Clinton in favor of then-U.S. Sen. Barack Obama. At the time Riley said he had been carefully watching the entire Democratic field, which he called “stellar,” but he ultimately decided Obama was the best.
